column4: In Debian, I configure the network in /etc/network/interfaces.  Where do I do the same thing in Ubuntu Jaunty?
any text files, or console apps?
So what you're telling me is there's no way to get ubuntu to use /etc/network/interfaces?
Or to use the command line, instead of forcing me to use the gui for everything?
you can manually set everything with /etc/network/interfaces
but Jaunty didn't read it on boot up
I'm tried to set network aliases.... i.e. eth0:0, eth0:1, eth0:2, eth0:3, ...
can you ifdown eth1         then ifup eth1
It's working, as long as I don't put eth0 in /etc/network/interfaces
as soon as I put eth0's definition in there, and then reboot, it all goes to hell in a handbasket

/etc/network/interfaces doesn't get initialized during bootup, and I'm guessing that's because whenever interfaces gets loaded, it's before network-manager gets run, and so eth0 doesn't exist yet, and consequently I cannot assign virtual interfaces to it
are you getting eth0 no such device error?
